newsitem.title: GERMANY: EU rapeseed losses seen offset by weak demand.
newsitem.headline: EU rapeseed losses seen offset by weak demand.

text.p: The impact of harvest losses on the European rapeseed market this year will be offset by a lack of demand for vegetable oils, a trader said on Wednesday.
Seed crushers were so unhappy with their margins that they were planning plant stoppages, said Bernd Koelln of Deutsche Conti at a seminar organised by grain trade paper Ernaehrungsdienst.
He forecast the 1996/97 EU rapeseed crush at 6.0-6.3 million tonnes compared with 7.8 million in 1995/96.
The EU rapeseed crop this year may fall to 6.9 million tonnes from 8.2 million, the Oil World newsletter said on Tuesday, citing a decline in area and poor weather.
Koelln said cif north European rapeseed oil at $575 was $35-40 too expensive when compared with Latin American sun oil and U.S. soyoil and given the high level of Rotterdam oil stocks.
Rapeseed sellers were asking 465 marks but crushers could operate profitably only if prices were cut by about 25 marks or if product prices rose as a result of a sudden surge in demand.
Koelln said seed crush margins in parts of Europe were just $15 a tonne, compared with crushers' expectations of nearer $40.
But Koelln said EU seed prices may fall under pressure from Canadian canola exports from November onwards.
The EU was also unlikely to export seed to Japan or Mexico as in recent years.
Despite this, farmers were storing rapeseed in the hope of higher prices next year.
He noted that the market could also be affected by higher Asian oilmeal consumption, falling world rapeseed stocks and a depletion of vegetable oil stocks in the U.S. and Latin America.
This in turn would make an impact on European stocks levels.
